abstract.p: Theodore Jay Miller reply to Cardinal Roger Mahony's June 2 letter holds right to choose means right to choose whether or not to have abortion

block.p: Let me clarify Cardinal Roger Mahony's ''clarity'' on the right to choose (letter, June 2). This right is not just the right to have an abortion; it's the right to choose whether or not to have an abortion.

A pregnant woman who chooses to have a child is exercising the same right as one who chooses to terminate her pregnancy; it's a ''seamless cloth,'' a single right protected by Roe v. Wade. If it's a woman's choice to make, then the government can't force her in either direction, no matter who she is.

Let me clarify Cardinal Roger Mahony's ''clarity'' on the right to choose (letter, June 2). This right is not just the right to have an abortion; it's the right to choose whether or not to have an abortion.

A pregnant woman who chooses to have a child is exercising the same right as one who chooses to terminate her pregnancy; it's a ''seamless cloth,'' a single right protected by Roe v. Wade. If it's a woman's choice to make, then the government can't force her in either direction, no matter who she is.

And if this is changed, so that it's not a woman's choice, then the government will choose whether or not a woman gets an abortion, and it may well force choices on women that someone like Cardinal Mahony will find objectionable.
THEODORE JAY MILLER Howard Beach, Queens, June 2, 2000
